items.standfirst: First Black woman to sit on central bank’s board accused by ally of president of mortgage fraudUS politics live – latest updatesDonald Trump has called on a Federal Reserve governor to immediately resign, renewing his extraordinary attack on the central bank’s independence as officials mull next steps on interest rates.A close Trump ally accused Lisa Cook, an appointee of Joe Biden, of “potentially committing mortgage fraud” and urged the US Department of Justice to investigate. The claims have not been confirmed. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel approves settlement project that could divide the West Bank
Israel set to approve settlement project that could divide the West Bank
items.standfirst: Israel on Wednesday gave approval for a controversial settlement project in the occupied West Bank’s E1 area, a move Palestinians and rights groups warn could effectively block a future Palestinian state. The development, long frozen under US pressure, has been backed by far-right Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich as a challenge to Western countries recognising a Palestinian state. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky has the details from Jerusalem.
items.content: Israel on Wednesday gave approval for a controversial settlement project in the occupied West Bank’s E1 area, a move Palestinians and rights groups warn could effectively block a future Palestinian state. The development, long frozen under US pressure, has been backed by far-right Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich as a challenge to Western countries recognising a Palestinian state. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky has the details from Jerusalem.

items.title: At least 78 people killed as bus collides with fuel truck in western Afghanistan
items.standfirst: Children among dead after bus carrying Afghans deported from Iran crashed and caught fire in Herat province Seventy-eight people have died in western Afghanistan in a collision between a bus carrying Afghans who had recently been deported from Iran and two other vehicles.The bus hit a motorcycle and a truck transporting fuel on Tuesday night, causing an explosive fire in Guzara district, Herat province. Two of the three survivors later died of their injuries, officials said on Wednesday. Continue reading...
items.content: Children among dead after bus carrying Afghans deported from Iran crashed and caught fire in Herat province Seventy-eight people have died in western Afghanistan in a collision between a bus carrying Afghans who had recently been deported from Iran and two other vehicles.The bus hit a motorcycle and a truck transporting fuel on Tuesday night, causing an explosive fire in Guzara district, Herat province. Two of the three survivors later died of their injuries, officials said on Wednesday. Continue reading...

items.title: Bus crash kills more than 70 Afghans deported from Iran, including 17 children

items.content: At least 75 people, including 17 children, have been killed in Afghanistan in a traffic accident involving a bus carrying migrants who were deported from Iran, officials said Wednesday.

ai_summary: A bus crash in Afghanistan's Herat province killed dozens.

items.title: Family of New Zealand fugitive on the run for almost four years with his children plead for his return
items.standfirst: In a New Zealand television interview, relatives spoke of their anguish since Tom Phillips disappeared with his three children in late 2021The family of a fugitive father who has been hiding for more than three years in New Zealand’s rugged wilderness with his three children has pleaded with the man to come home, in some of their first public comments since he vanished.Just before Christmas 2021, Tom Phillips fled into the Waikato wilderness with his children Ember, now 9, Maverick, 10, and Jayda, 12, following a dispute with their mother. Phillips does not have legal custody of his children. Continue reading...
items.content: In a New Zealand television interview, relatives spoke of their anguish since Tom Phillips disappeared with his three children in late 2021The family of a fugitive father who has been hiding for more than three years in New Zealand’s rugged wilderness with his three children has pleaded with the man to come home, in some of their first public comments since he vanished.Just before Christmas 2021, Tom Phillips fled into the Waikato wilderness with his children Ember, now 9, Maverick, 10, and Jayda, 12, following a dispute with their mother. items.title: Walmart recalls potentially radioactive shrimp sold in 13 US states

clusters.title: Macron hits out at ‘abject’ Netanyahu claim of rise in antisemitism in France
clusters.neutral_headline: Macron Rebukes Netanyahu Over Antisemitism Claims

items.title: Macron hits out at ‘abject’ Netanyahu claim of rise in antisemitism in France
items.standfirst: French president responds to Israeli PM’s ‘erroneous’ allegations in relation to decision to recognise state of Palestine Emmanuel Macron has hit out at Benjamin Netanyahu for his “abject” and “erroneous” remarks after Israel’s prime minister claimed that antisemitism had “surged” in France after the country’s decision to recognise a Palestinian state in September.In a statement released late on Tuesday, the office of the French president pushed back against Netanyahu’s claim. “The analysis suggesting that France’s decision to recognise the state of Palestine in September is behind the rise in antisemitic violence in France is erroneous, abject, and will not go unanswered,” it said. “The current period calls for seriousness and responsibility, not generalisation and manipulation.” Continue reading...
items.content: French president responds to Israeli PM’s ‘erroneous’ allegations in relation to decision to recognise state of Palestine Emmanuel Macron has hit out at Benjamin Netanyahu for his “abject” and “erroneous” remarks after Israel’s prime minister claimed that antisemitism had “surged” in France after the country’s decision to recognise a Palestinian state in September.In a statement released late on Tuesday, the office of the French president pushed back against Netanyahu’s claim. “The analysis suggesting that France’s decision to recognise the state of Palestine in September is behind the rise in antisemitic violence in France is erroneous, abject, and will not go unanswered,” it said. “The current period calls for seriousness and responsibility, not generalisation and manipulation.” Continue reading...

items.title: Paris rebuffs Netanyahu over accusations of antisemitism
items.standfirst: After Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accused French President Emmanuel Macron of “fueling antisemitism” by backing recognition of a Palestinian state, the Élysée hit back. In a statement, the French presidency called the remarks “abject” and “erroneous,” stressing that France will always stand by its Jewish citizens and that Netanyahu’s claims “will not go unanswered.”
items.content: After Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accused French President Emmanuel Macron of “fueling antisemitism” by backing recognition of a Palestinian state, the Élysée hit back. In a statement, the French presidency called the remarks “abject” and “erroneous,” stressing that France will always stand by its Jewish citizens and that Netanyahu’s claims “will not go unanswered.”

ai_summary: Macron criticized Netanyahu's remarks on antisemitism in France.
Netanyahu claimed antisemitism surged after France recognized Palestine.
The French presidency called Netanyahu's remarks "abject" and "erroneous".
France stated it will always stand by its Jewish citizens.
The French presidency said Netanyahu's claims will not go unanswered.

clusters.title: France questions online violence after streamer’s live death

items.title: France questions online violence after streamer’s live death
items.standfirst: French prosecutors are investigating the death of a 46-year-old streamer who collapsed during a live broadcast on the online platform Kick, where he was seen being mistreated by others on screen. The case has sparked debate in France over the platform’s responsibility and the risks of such extreme live content.
items.content: French prosecutors are investigating the death of a 46-year-old streamer who collapsed during a live broadcast on the online platform Kick, where he was seen being mistreated by others on screen. The case has sparked debate in France over the platform’s responsibility and the risks of such extreme live content.

items.title: Police investigating death of French streamer seize equipment and videos
items.standfirst: Raphaël Graven - also known as Jeanpormanove - was known for his extreme videos on the platform, Kick.
items.content: Raphaël Graven - also known as Jeanpormanove - was known for his extreme videos on the platform, Kick.

items.title: France probes live streaming death of man
items.standfirst: Prosecutors in Nice are investigating the death of 46-year-old Raphael Graven, known online as “Jean Pormanove” or “JP,” who collapsed during a live-streamed show in which he was being mistreated. The video, broadcast on the platform Kick, showed him lying motionless under a blanket as one of two men in the room threw a bottle towards him.
items.content: Prosecutors in Nice are investigating the death of 46-year-old Raphael Graven, known online as “Jean Pormanove” or “JP,” who collapsed during a live-streamed show in which he was being mistreated. The video, broadcast on the platform Kick, showed him lying motionless under a blanket as one of two men in the room threw a bottle towards him.

ai_summary: French prosecutors are investigating a streamer's death.
The streamer collapsed during a live broadcast on Kick.
The streamer was known as Jeanpormanove.
The video showed mistreatment of the streamer.
Police seized equipment and videos related to the death.

items.title: Air Canada flight attendants reach ‘tentative’ deal with airline to end strike
items.standfirst: Strike over wages and ground work has cancelled travel for 500,000 people worldwideAir Canada flight attendants say they have reached a “tentative” deal with the airline to end a strike over wages and ground work that has cancelled travel for half a million people worldwide.Roughly 10,000 flight attendants walked off the job after midnight Saturday, insisting Air Canada had failed to address their demands for higher pay and compensation for unpaid ground work, including during boarding. Continue reading...

items.title: Air Canada and flight attendants reach tentative deal to end strike
items.standfirst: The Air Canada strike has ended after flight attendants reached a tentative agreement with the airline, both parties said early Tuesday."The Strike has ended," the Canadian Union of Public Employees said in a Facebook post advising its membership to "fully cooperate with resumption of operations."
items.content: The Air Canada strike has ended after flight attendants reached a tentative agreement with the airline, both parties said early Tuesday."The Strike has ended," the Canadian Union of Public Employees said in a Facebook post advising its membership to "fully cooperate with resumption of operations."

ai_summary: Air Canada flight attendants reached a tentative deal.
The deal ends a strike over wages and ground work.
The strike had canceled travel for 500,000 people.
Roughly 10,000 flight attendants walked off the job.
The union advised members to cooperate with operations.
